abstract: pmc BMB Rep BMB Rep 2515 bmbreps BMB Reports 1976-6696 1976-670X Korean Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology PMC12481284 PMC12481284.1 12481284 12481284 40754779 10.5483/BMBRep.2025-0053 bmb-58-9-389 1 Invited Mini Review Roles of RNA modifications in aging and age-related diseases Kang Eunseok # Haque Rosa # Lee Hanseul Lee Seung-Jae V. * Department of Biological Sciences, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 34141, Korea * seungjaevlee@kaist.ac.kr # These authors contributed equally to this work. 30 9 2025 7 7 2025 58 9 497977 389 396 20 3 2025 2 5 2025 27 5 2025 07 07 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 Copyright © 2025 by the The Korean Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ This is an open-access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial License ( http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0 RNA modifications are key epigenetic alterations that play regulatory functions in RNA biology, including RNA stability and translation. Emerging evidence indicates that RNA modification is crucial for various physiological and pathological processes, including aging. This review describes functions of key RNA modifications, including N 6 6 5 N 7 7 N 1 1 Age-related diseases Aging Longevity RNA modification Senescence National Research Foundation of Korea http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/501100003725 RS-2024-00408712 Ministry of Science and ICT, South Korea http://dx.doi.org/10.13039/501100014188 RS-2024-00408712 pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes INTRODUCTION Aging is a progressive decline in cellular and physiological functions that increases susceptibility to various diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease (AD), Parkinson’s disease (PD), and cardiovascular diseases, leading to vulnerability to death ( 1 2 1 3 4 5 RNA modifications are key epigenetic alterations that play important regulatory roles in RNA quality, including stability, splicing, translation, transport, and localization ( 6 7 8 9 11 In this review, we describe the roles of various RNA modifications in aging, and their association with age-related diseases. We describe key RNA modifications ( Fig. 1 N 6 6 N 6 6 7 12 6 6 13 14 6 15 9 6 6 16 17 6 N 6 18 19 μ 6 20 21 6 20 6 6 21 6 NPNT 21 22 25 6 Multiple studies have provided evidence for crucial roles of 42 NSUN2 45 5 p21 26 5 NSUN2 43 44 5 5 5 N 7 7 N 7 7 8 7 8 7 μ 7 Drosophila 46 7 Mettl1 Drosophila METTL1/CG4045 METTL1 WDR4 METTL1 7 7 2’-O-methylation (Nm) 2’-O-methylation (Nm) is an abundant and highly conserved RNA modification, in which a methyl group is added to the ribose moiety ( 47 48 Nm is essential for stability of small RNAs, including miRNAs, which play crucial roles in aging processes ( 49 Drosophila 50 Ago2 Hen1 HENMT1 Drosophila Drosophila 51 52 52 51 N 1 1 N 1 1 53 1 1 m 1 54 56 56 TRMT10C 56 1 2 57 58 1 54 55 1 MFAP2 55 1 CSF1 54 1 CSF1 1 1 Adenosine-to-inosine editing (A-to-I editing) Adenosine-to-inosine editing (A-to-I editing) converts adenosine nucleotide to inosine within double-stranded RNAs ( 59 61 A-to-I editing is essential for gene regulation and transcriptomic diversity, and is implicated in organismal aging across species, including C. elegans 62 63 adr-2 C. elegans 63 ADAR2 ADAR3 62 C. elegans 64 C. elegans A-to-I editing is decreased in age-associated neurological disorders such as AD ( 65 66 65 66 67 Pseudouridylation (ψ) Pseudouridylation (ψ) is abundantly detected in the majority of eukaryotic RNA classes, including tRNAs, snRNAs, snoRNAs, miRNAs, and mRNAs ( 68 69 The dynamics of ψ and the ψ-modulating enzymes change during organismal aging and cellular senescence ( 64 70 C. elegans 64 C. elegans 70 DKC1 71 Dkc1 72 N4-acetylcytidine (ac4C) N4-acetylcytidine (ac4C) modification is a highly conserved RNA modification in prokaryotes and eukaryotes ( 73 74 The role of NAT10 is implicated in age-related diseases, including cancer and AD ( 75 79 76 79 76 78 75 CONCLUSIONS Here, we described various chemical modifications of RNAs, focusing on m 6 5 7 1 Fig. 2 Despite the progress on the roles of diverse RNA modifications in aging and age-related diseases, numerous questions remain unanswered. Mechanisms by which specific RNA modifications are altered during aging and their causal roles that regulate regulating organismal aging remain mostly elusive. For instance, while an age-associated increase in A-to-I editing and ψ has been reported in C. elegans 1 By expanding our understanding of RNA functions and modulation methods, RNA-based therapeutics are rapidly emerging as a promising therapeutic strategy ( 80 84 85 86 85 86 ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS This work was supported by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grant funded by the Korea government (MSIT) (RS-2024-00408712) to S.J.V.L. The authors utilized ChatGPT 4o (OpenAI) to improve language clarity of the manuscript.  CONFLICTS OF INTEREST The authors have no conflicting interests.
